string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To preview this video, use the Preview functionality in Storyline, republish your course using standard MP4 video, or publish to Review 360.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Capital Asset Information Form for Requisitions

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Please click the exit button to record your participation in this course." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

terms.term: An Add-on is a component $5,000 or more that is permanently added to another piece of inventorial equipment. The pump would be an add-on if it was purchased to add to any inventorial asset that needed an additional pump. This inventorial asset would already have a university property number assigned.
Used interchangeably to refer to the new financial system for UC Davis

BUS-29 establishes policy and procedures for the management and control of inventorial equipment owned by, or in the custody of, the University. Feel free to click the link to learn more about the policy.

Also known as the EQ Form, it is required to be attached to a requisition with a capital asset. The questions in the form provide the information needed to ensure the equipment gets recorded in the Aggie Enterprise system correctly.

A capital equipment asset is tangible, movable property that has a useful life expectancy of more than one year and a per-unit acquisition cost of $5,000.00 or more. Capital equipment is also known as equipment, inventorial equipment, or capital assets. Examples include microscopes, ultrasounds, freezers, vehicles, IT equipment, etc.
A capital equipment asset is tangible, moveable property that has a useful life expectancy of more than one year and a per-unit acquisition cost of $5,000.00 or more.

Components are items that are necessary to place the equipment into its intended location and condition for use.They are bought at the same time as the main item, usually on the same PO. An example could be a pump that is part of an LC/MS system.

A Fabrication is a tangible, non-consumable item that has been physically constructed by a university activity. It has a total fabricated cost of at least $5,000 and is expected to be used by the University upon completion for at least one year or more. It is not a product resulting from simple assembly or connecting of various parts and is not a deliverable.
A subledger in the Aggie Enterprise system, used to manage movable and non-movable assets.
Non-capital assets are equipment that is less than $5,000 per item, it is consumed in one year or less, it is permanently installed into a structure, or it is a repair/replacement item.

Determined the classification of an item. It is similar to the commodity codes in KFS. The category (along with dollar amount) determines whether the purchase gets categorized as a Capital Equipment asset in Aggie Enterprise.

Offers a tax reduction of -3.9375%. To be eligible three criteria must be met: o The unit cost is 5K or more (pre-tax), o The asset will remain in California exclusively for the first twelve months; o The asset will be used for research at least 50% of the time.
An item purchased in order to restore the functionality of a broken or unusable asset.
